@tysonnorris Should we also make controller id stable with an approach similar to one taken in Invoker based on zookeeper? As currently it leads to creation of many topics if the id is based on say ip
@chetanmeh agree this would be better, but afaik invoker suffers the same (1 topic per ip, when id is based on ip); can you log an issue to track this?
Opened #3858 to track this

@tysonnorris mentioned [here][1]

> invoker suffers the same (1 topic per ip, when id is based on ip)

One possible approach would be to support expiring the mappings via some external agent and then have id logic to pickup first unused from the sequence. Recently in Apache Jackrabbit Oak we faced [similar issue][2] and @mreutegg implemented a greedy logic to acquire clusterId.

As for expiry - For Mesos we can have a service which listens to task status event and if it finds an invoker getting terminated then it can remove the corresponding entry from the `/invokers/idAssignment/mapping` path in zookeeper. Thus later once new invoker comes up it can claim that id.

[1]: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3507#issuecomment-403519143
[2]: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/OAK-7316

Currently, the kubernetes client tests are made by mock client with limited number of test cases. After removing `kubectl` commands, we can refactor our tests with more comprehensive test cases by using [mock kubernetes server](https://github.com/fabric8io/kubernetes-client#mocking-kubernetes).

Adding further ... below is a possible approach to use to get a stable id for a cluster consisting of "N" entities. Objective here is to have a sequential id with id getting reused in case the backing entity stops 

### A - Check id validity on startup

Assume ids are stored under path
```
/invokers/idAssignment/mapping
+ 1 - u1 //Some unique id
+ 2 - u2 //another unique id
```

At startup `IdAllocator` does following steps

1. List the entries under `/invokers/idAssignment/mapping`
2. For each entry get its unique id. The unique id can be
    - Mesos - [MESOS_TASK_ID][1] (also see [docs here][2])
    - k8s - [Pod id][3]
3. Check if the container for given id is still in running state. This logic can be part of an `IdStalenessChecker` SPI
    - Mesos - via [task api][4]
    - k8s - To be figured out
4. If not found in running state then make a reservation by setting your own id against the given entry or add a new entry

### B - Use TTL Ids

Use Curator [Persistent TTL Nodes][5] recipe to add a node with ttl. 

Benefit of "A" is that it would not add any load to zookeeper or etcd. While "B" is simpler to implement

[1]: https://mesosphere.github.io/marathon/docs/task-environment-vars.html#task-metadata
[3]: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/inject-data-application/environment-variable-expose-pod-information/#use-pod-fields-as-values-for-environment-variables
[2]: http://mesos.apache.org/api/latest/java/org/apache/mesos/Protos.TaskID.html
[4]: http://mesos.apache.org/documentation/latest/endpoints/master/tasks/
[5]: https://curator.apache.org/curator-recipes/persistent-ttl-node.html
yep, by the time we get to line 133, we know that the invokerName is a non-empty String.  it should be unwrapped.  @chetanmeh do you want to do a PR with the fix?
Thanks @dgrove-oss for the test patch and @markusthoemmes for the singleton suggestion.

Why is a stable identifier strictly needed for a defined amount of controllers? To avoid stale topics strictly? Note that while the invokers need a stable incrementing number as their identifier, this is no longer true for the controllers.

If it's just stale topics, could we possibly configure kafka to throw topics away that are stale for a while?

@markusthoemmes From what I understand even Invokers currently not have very stable ids. So there are two parts to problem

### Controller Stable Id

Here requirement is that current approach may lead to orphan topics in Kafka if controller restarts and chooses a new id for every run. So here we either go for stable id or have a way in Kafka to expire topics which do not see some activity after some time

### Invoker Stable Id

Currently Invokers make use of `--name` parameter to be provided a unique name which is then used to find a mapping id from zookeeper. The problem (at least for Mesos) is that there is no stable unique name parameter value to use. One can use the host ip but then it would vary if the next restart leads to  container being placed on different host.

Looking at [kube][1] setup it looks like it is using [StatefulSet][2] to keep stable id across restarts. So for Mesos we can also use similar [Persistent Volume][3] 

However I am not sure if using stateful feature of container runtime should be the way to go as it would cause issue in case that node gives a problem or goes offline. In such a case invoker would be started on a new node and that would cause the topic to become orphan leaving activations present in  it unprocessed.

Hence the search for newer approach

[1]: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-deploy-kube/blob/489ce8e90abf3bc411f8dd7087d42916c8a004be/helm/openwhisk/templates/invoker.yaml#L99
[2]: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/workloads/controllers/statefulset/
[3]: https://mesosphere.github.io/marathon/docs/persistent-volumes.html

> How about using akka clustering for id mapping resolution?

@tysonnorris Missed that we can also use that. Yes that should also provide a simpler solution. We anyway rely on akka networking in controller so possibly can use that for invokers also.

The only concern there is that having unique id in case of [split deployments][1] would be problematic and default Akka setup does not have good support to handle that. Gievn container managed runtime provide a stable consistent view of cluster it may be more reliable to use there state to determine the current state of system and assign ids 

[1]: https://developer.lightbend.com/docs/akka-commercial-addons/current/split-brain-resolver.html

Hmm, it feels like the hunt for a stable identifier is a red herring here. The concern is mostly stale topics in Kafka, correct?

So for the Controller, that shouldn't be much of an issue if we just garbage collect stale topics after, say, 24 hours of inactivity. Inactivity means: No consumers connected for that time. There might even be a way to configure Kafka to do that.

Same for the invokers. Yes, there might be a (small) amount of activations residing on a topic when an invoker is disappearing. But not that these would be lost if they went into the invoker anyway. That amount should be very small (< `invokerBusyThreshold`) and that is the amount of messages that we allow to get lost anyway?

For the overflow case of course, this is different. We should strive for the overflow queue there though vs. fixing the ID mappings.

Another angle to this is: Instead of trying to fix invoker id assignments (which are kinda important to be increments of 1) should we try to find an algorithm, that doesn't rely on numbered invokers at all?

Unique name[1] is used for dynamic kafka topic assignment while display name[2] is for the mapping between invoker container name and its kafka topic. 
For the case of Kube based deployments, we use worker node ip addresses as [1]. This allows invoker topic stickiness for the case of worker OS reload. 
[2] is the invoker docker container name in kube. If one deploys Invokers as k8s "Deployment" each node gets it container name dynamically in a form `invoker-j8ptk`, currently each invoker reports its status via health protocol in a form `invoker0`. And we cannot say which invoker topic belongs to which invoker container in the deployment. Thus [2] is a conventional mapping between invoker topic and actual container name we see in kube.

In theory I can pack [2] into [1], but then each time the worker node gets OS reloaded, the invoker container will receive a new container name, which means that a new kafka topic will be created. This could potentially cause an issue, e.g. if Kafka topic of the invoker was not empty before the reload its activations will hang on that topic.

Thanks @vvraskin for the improvements and addressing the comments. The comment about kafka topics may be superficially related to @markusthoemmes' point here https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/3858#issuecomment-404059138.

This looks good to me now.  Since we are deploying on several different container orchestration systems, I think it is useful have separate "names" to distinguish between a transient container name vs. a logical invoker name vs. a kafka topic used by the load balancer (which because of the current load balancer implementation is effectively constrained to be a densely back natural number).
LGTM.

> So for the Controller, that shouldn't be much of an issue if we just garbage collect stale topics after, say, 24 hours of inactivity. Inactivity means: No consumers connected for that time. There might even be a way to configure Kafka to do that.

Did not found any out of the box Kafka feature to do that. So we would need to have some tooling to do the purge. May be we add that support in `wskadmin-next`

> For the overflow case of course, this is different. We should strive for the overflow queue there though vs. fixing the ID mappings.

My concern was more for overflow case. As there would always be case where OW capacity may be limited and in case of burst of events the queue size may grow large. So yes probably overflow queue concept should be implemented

> Another angle to this is: Instead of trying to fix invoker id assignments (which are kinda important to be increments of 1) should we try to find an algorithm, that doesn't rely on numbered invokers at all?

Well thinking about this it appears what we are doing is similar to what Kafka would be doing internally via partitions support. If you have a single queue and multiple invokers form a consumer group then internally Kafka would parition the queue and allocate the partitions to individual invokers. So it would internally take care of sequential numbering of partitions.

So just for thought process lets say if we have a single Kafka queue and then following model can be implemented

1. The global topic use action name + namespace as partition key
2. Multiple invokers form a consumer group and subscribe to the above topic 
3. Each invoker then processed activations from the assigned partitions.

Such an approach would enable

1. Single stable topic
2. Simplify scaling by adding new invokers to share load and let Kafka rebalance the partitions to consumer group members
3. Partitioning by action + namespace would ensure stickiness to the invoker and would have same effect as current sharding load balancer strategy
Closing for now, will redo at some point.
